skill.name: biomni
skill.description: Autonomous biomedical AI agent framework for executing complex research tasks across genomics, drug discovery, molecular biology, and clinical analysis. Use this skill when conducting multi-step biomedical research including CRISPR screening design, single-cell RNA-seq analysis, ADMET prediction, GWAS interpretation, rare disease diagnosis, or lab protocol optimization. Leverages LLM reasoning with code execution and integrated biomedical databases.
skill.summary: Autonomous biomedical AI agent framework for executing complex research tasks across genomics, drug ...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: Biomni is a legitimate biomedical research framework from Stanford that requires code execution capabilities for its core functionality. While static analysis flags many security patterns, these are necessary for an AI agent that generates and executes analysis code. The skill includes proper security warnings and recommends sandboxed execution.

content.user_title: Automate biomedical research with AI agents
content.value_statement: Biomni transforms complex biomedical research by autonomously executing multi-step analysis tasks. Researchers can focus on scientific questions while AI handles data processing, literature review, and computational analysis across genomics, drug discovery, and clinical domains.
actual_capabilities: Design CRISPR screens with sgRNA library optimization
Analyze single-cell RNA-seq data with automated cell type annotation
Predict ADMET properties for drug candidate compounds
Interpret GWAS results and identify causal variants
Generate Python/R code for custom biomedical analyses
limitations: Requires API keys for LLM providers (Anthropic/OpenAI)
Downloads 11GB biomedical databases on first use
Code execution requires trusted environment setup
Limited to biomedical and life sciences domains

use_cases.title: Design genome-wide CRISPR screens
use_cases.description: Automate sgRNA library design, gene prioritization, and knockout effect analysis for functional genomics studies

use_cases.title: Process single-cell sequencing data
use_cases.description: Perform quality control, clustering, cell type annotation, and differential expression analysis

use_cases.title: Predict compound ADMET properties
use_cases.description: Evaluate absorption, distribution, metabolism, excretion, and toxicity for drug candidates

prompt_templates.title: CRISPR Screen Design
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a CRISPR knockout screen to identify genes regulating autophagy in HEK293 cells. Include sgRNA library design, positive/negative controls, and gene prioritization based on pathway relevance.

prompt_templates.title: Single-Cell Analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze this single-cell RNA-seq dataset: perform QC, identify cell populations via clustering, annotate cell types using marker genes, and conduct differential expression. File: path/to/data.h5ad

prompt_templates.title: GWAS Interpretation
prompt_templates.prompt: Interpret GWAS results for Type 2 Diabetes: identify genome-wide significant variants, map to causal genes, perform pathway enrichment, and predict functional consequences

prompt_templates.title: Drug ADMET Prediction
prompt_templates.prompt: Predict ADMET properties for these compounds: [SMILES strings]. Focus on Caco-2 permeability, plasma protein binding, CYP450 interactions, clearance, and hERG toxicity

output_examples.input: Design a CRISPR screen for autophagy regulators
output: â€¢ Generated sgRNA library with 76,230 guides targeting 19,057 genes
â€¢ Designed 4 sgRNAs per gene with on-target scores >0.7
â€¢ Included positive controls: ATG5, BECN1, ULK1, mTOR
â€¢ Prioritized 347 candidate genes based on pathway analysis
â€¢ Provided Python code for screen analysis pipeline
â€¢ Estimated screening requirements and timeline

best_practices: Specify biological context including organism, cell type, and experimental conditions
Provide data file paths when analyzing datasets
Set computational constraints for complex analyses
anti_patterns: Running without reviewing generated code in production environments
Sharing API keys or credentials in shared environments
Processing sensitive clinical data without proper authorization
Ignoring timeout settings for long-running analyses

faq.question: Is biomni safe to use?
faq.answer: Yes, biomni is from Stanford's SNAP lab. Run in isolated environments as it executes generated code with system privileges.

faq.question: What LLM providers does biomni support?
faq.answer: Anthropic Claude (recommended), OpenAI GPT, Google Gemini, Groq, Azure OpenAI, and AWS Bedrock.

faq.question: How much data does biomni download?
faq.answer: Approximately 11GB of biomedical databases including gene annotations, protein structures, and clinical datasets.

faq.question: Can biomni analyze my experimental data?
faq.answer: Yes, provide file paths to your datasets in natural language queries. Supports common formats like FASTA, BAM, VCF, and HDF5.

faq.question: What domains does biomni cover?
faq.answer: Genomics, proteomics, drug discovery, clinical genomics, molecular biology, and multi-omics integration.

faq.question: How do I cite biomni?
faq.answer: Reference the preprint: https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2025.05.30.656746v1 and GitHub repository.
